job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I have had the chance to see the company more than double in size since I joined and it has been amazing to see how much everyone cares deeply about the future of education and Minerva's mission. Having Minerva Schools and Minerva Project working side by side has allowed the company to build a solid foundation and they can now leverage those learnings to support new partners very effectively.

Just like many companies facing a quick growth, there were bumps on the road during the transition, but I think leadership has been very open and receptive to feedback which has helped going over the hump. Now things feel more mature, teams are better organized, the company is in a great position to move forward and accelerate its development.

The product team is still small (~20 people) but extremely competent! Even though people have areas of expertise, everybody is full-stack and gets to wear many hats. The team is diverse, distributed across the US, Europe and Middle East, and very remote friendly. There is a lot of trust and support from the managers and they really try their best to help you grow your technical and soft skills.

Over the past year, there has been a tremendous effort to update the tech stack to newer technology, from the frontend (migrating Backbone to React), to the backend (migrating all services to python 3), and infrastructure (moving from opsworks to kubernetes). A lot of automation and code quality improvements have been put in place as well and engineers actively engage in weekly meetings for knowledge sharing and technology centered discussions.
cons:
Having a small team lets you grow your skills in multiple directions and at a pretty fast pace, but the downside is that the number of roles is limited (for now). Another issue with having a small team and a quickly growing business, is that some things don't scale very well. For example, it's hard to keep up with new bugs and features while staying on track with planned work.

Since COVID, even though things like "donut" on slack have been put in place to facilitate meeting new people in the organization, it's harder to create tight bonds with other teams like it used to be possible to when everybody was gathering at the yearly all company event.

job_title: Engineering Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Having worked at Minerva for >5 years I've gotten to see it in a variety of stages of development. As we've transitioned from audacious idea and scrappy startup into early maturity, there have been opportunities to wear a wide variety of hats, to take on a lot of responsibility, and to grow professionally as a result. I've enjoyed being pushed to grow by a super talented group of engineers, PMs, and designers, as well as in my cross-functional work with incredibly sharp and thoughtful coworkers on other teams.

Working with students in a variety of contexts had been stimulating - I've gotten the opportunity to work with students in technical work-study positions, to manage student teams  during summer internships, participate in student events, and share career advice with some of our soon-to-be-graduates.

Getting to dogfood Minerva classes (e.g. currently trialing a forthcoming management and complexity science course aimed at graduate and professional levels) is awesome.

It's been incredibly satisfying seeing the hypotheses about better higher education come to fruition as we went from no students to graduating our first class. My experience on the Product (engineering) team have been one characterized by a surprising amount of stability and work/life balance compared to other companies I've seen peers at during a similar point in company development. I've also gotten the pleasure of working with teammates for an a period of time that's unusual in Silicon Valley startup land - roughly one quarter of the Product team over time had tenures of over 4 years, and the average tenure is a little over 3 years (including folks who were hired fewer than 3 years ago).
cons: The transition from scrappy startup to mature organization wasn't always smooth. It was a challenge to move from a colocated company to a distributed one, and we had to develop skills and structures (remote-first, more async communication, more proactive checkin on the part of management) along the. Staffing levels have been a concern for various teams at various times -- as we built a university from scratch we didn't always predict staffing needs accurately and this required people to stretch to cover student needs. I think that the experience of folks on the Product (engineering) about sustainable work pace and work/life balance are not reflective of the experiences that others have had.

job_title: Senior Engineer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Having followed the educational technology industry for many years, I can confidently say that Minerva is one of the few companies that deeply care about improving student learning - on the one hand boldly believing that they can do far better than even elite universities currently do, on the other hand being humble enough to realise that we have much to learn and that success comes from strong first principles, and then an ongoing process of continuous improvement. I have been very impressed by how closely engineers and product managers work with curriculum developers and students to create more engaging experiences.

The engineering team is very diverse, highly remote-friendly, and consists of people who are both technically very strong, but also all motivated by the mission of Minerva. We work very closely with faculty, students and partners, and are able to have a lot of input into feature design, technical approaches and execution. Product team is only about 25 people, so nobody is "just a number", everyone have their unique skills and approaches to contribute, and my manager has been very supportive in thinking about how to grow and develop, not just as an engineer. Communication in the whole organization (almost 180 people at this time) is very fluid and open, and we often get to interact with faculty teams, but also student experience, strategic partnerships etc.
cons: There is a fair amount of technical debt, and a lot of the stack is based on old technology (Backbone, Django DRF), although that is slowly changing. We are very proactive about testing, but engineers often have to jump in and help with escalated issues - while it's good to see firsthand the pain points of customers, I hope we can get to a point where we will feel more confident in the code. Part of the reason, apart from the old code, is that we're currently expanding from our main partner (Minerva Schools) to a number of new partners, each requiring a fair amount of customization etc as we work on "crossing the chasm".
